climbs.name: What's Hannen
climbs.fa: Jack Roberts, Kevin Powell, and Alan Roberts, 1981

content.description: An awkward exit from an alcove (crux) leads to a hand crack, and then to some easier steep face climbing.  This route is in shade most of the time.

climbs.name: Turning Tricks
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Frank Bentwood and Kelly Vaught, October 2014

content.description:
This variation finish turns a good route into a great one.

Climb the crux of Single Cat Leg, then hand traverse right on a rail to an extended move right into an overhanging seam. Clip a bolt, then climb a bouldery sequence through slightly overhanging rock to jugs. Move left to a shelf with a 2-bolt anchor.

Tricky, sustained, technical, and pumper at the finish, on great rock; this little gem is at the top of my list of "Best Trad Leads" in Rock Garden Valley.
content.protection:
Warning! The pro is bomber but difficult to place. I led this route after toprope rehearsal.

Take a good selection of small CDs from .3 to .75 inches. One bolt.

climbs.name: The Treat
climbs.fa: (TR) Ellen Holden, Pete Warren & Tom Beck, June 1998, FL: Tom Beck & Ellen Holden, July 1998

content.description:
Well worth doing if in the area, this fun route starts up a flake to reach the generously protected upper face which is sort of an easy version of

Bebop Tango

. Two stars out of five.

Gear belay and downclimb to climber's left.

Scramble up easy rock to a ledge and then climb cracks to access the juggy face above. Follow the largest and most obvious jugs up to a single bolt and continue straight up (5.8) or cut left via easier terrain (5.6).
content.protection:
Gear to 4 inches, one bolt (3/8"); large cams (#3-4) on top for the anchor.

Bolt upgraded 5/2014
content.location:
Swiss Cheese

ascends the left side of a steep and extremely knobby face about halfway up the right side of the canyon (~100' down-canyon from

Double Dogleg

).

climbs.name: Single Cat Leg (aka Why Does it Hurt When I Pee?)

content.description: Climb the tricky thin crack on the left side of the formation, finishing with an easier handcrack.
content.protection: Gear from 0.25 to 3 inches. Anchors/rap rings at the top

content.description: Start on right leaning crack which then travels up a vertical crack with a slight left jog then straight up to the summit.
content.protection: standard rack, create your own anchor.  Rappel anchor can be found at the right end of the formation as you face the route.
content.location: This route is located on the lower shorter wall.  There are about a half a dozen routes on the lower end - Mr. Michael Goes to WA is the last route as you go up canyon towards the upper shorter wall.

climbs.name: Marion Barry Goes to Washington
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mike Moretti, May 2015

content.description:
Climb the face between Mr. Michael Goes to Washington and Blue Sky Black Death.

Start just left of Blue Sky Black Death with a few face moves up to a discontinuous thin crack, then step left and climb a steep friction slab, with a mantle past a horizontal just before the finishing moves.
content.protection: A rigging rope is useful to setup a TR using a huge block.

content.description: Starts off with a variety of easy hand cracks at the base. As you move up the first 20 feet or so you will find a dual crack system that is perfect for hand jams. Continue to the small alcove near the top, and at this point you have the option to enter an offwidth crack or traverse right for a section of slab. Belay your partner up from the alcove, and walk to the bolted anchors atop Mr. Michael Goes to Washington.
content.protection: Plenty of 1's and 2's for BD Camalot. You may also need some 4's for the bigger crack at the top of the route.
content.location: It is found just to the left of Mr. Michael Goes to Washington. Look for the series of crack that drop below the top of Blue Sky Black Death to the left.

climbs.name: Cuban Sandwich
climbs.fa: (TR) Ron Herschberg and Bob Gaines, April 2014,  First Lead: Bob Gaines and Frank Bentwood, June, 2014.

content.description:
This variation climbs the varnished face of a small pillar between What's Hannen and Swiss Cheese. The crux is well-protected, on great rock. Finish with an easier but runout face (5.6 R) up to the bolt on Swiss Cheese for a 5.8 finish.

Gear anchor: CD's from 2 to 4 inches.

This route climbs from a ramp at the base of the walls rightmost promminent crack/chimney  feature,sharing the start with neighboriong climb to the right " Barn Door Left ". BSBD  climbs  up and left on easy 5th to the crux section( 5.6), 2 sections of OK cracks to the top.
content.protection: pro - 3 " will have to build your top belay anchors, however rap/ top rope anchors existis  on the N./  end of the formation. I am not aware of a walk of decent.

content.description: Rather than cutting left in the alcove up the hand crack, it goes straight up the gully through the flared offwidth to chimney as it widens and you search for small hand edges that rarely appear and wrong angled smears on the bulge to the left.
content.location:
Start is shared with

Blue Sky, Black Death

. Can rap down Bolivian Freeze Job to the right.
